title: 111_hr4908
content: The "Campus Fire Safety Education Act of 2010" aims to provide fire safety education to students at higher education institutions through the Campus Fire Safety Education Competitive Grant Program. The Secretary will establish a grant program to award grants to eligible entities for fire safety education programs at higher education institutions, with priority given to those planning to improve fire safety awareness among students. The Act allows grant funds for fire safety education programs tailored for students with disabilities. Grants are awarded for up to 2 years, with a possible renewal for another 2 years. Grant size is determined by the Secretary, capped at $250,000 per fiscal year. Recipients must provide a 25% non-Federal matching fund. Non-Federal matching funds must be at least 25% of the costs for activities. Funds from this Act should supplement, not replace, other Federal, State, or private funds for fire safety education programs. SEC. 4. REQUIRED USES OF FUNDS. An eligible entity receiving a grant under this Act must use the funds to implement a fire safety education program for all students, including those living on and off-campus. The program should involve outreach to students at least twice a year and provide fire safety information upon request. The fire safety education program funded by the grant must provide minimum instruction on fire behavior, mechanisms of fire injury, common ignition scenarios, fire safety systems, alarms, extinguishers, and means of egress. The program must also include evaluations on its effectiveness in increasing awareness and improving fire safety behavior within 6 months after the grant period. The entity must improve fire safety behavior and submit a report on the evaluation results to the Secretary. SEC. 5. REPORTS. The Secretary must report to Congress annually on the number and types of eligible entities receiving assistance, fire safety education programs, and any other relevant information to evaluate the effectiveness of the program in improving fire safety knowledge among college students. Additionally, a best practices report will be published using this information. A report of best practices for fire safety education programs will be published for institutions of higher education and interested parties. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "Administrator" refers to the head of the United States Fire Administration. The term "fire safety education program" pertains to activities focused on fire safety and prevention. "Institution of higher education" is defined as per the Higher Education Act of 1965. An "eligible entity" can be an institution of higher education collaborating with a nonprofit or fire safety organization. The term "Secretary" in this Act refers to the Secretary of Education. An eligible entity can be a nonprofit, public safety department, or a social fraternity/sorority exempt from taxation under the Internal Revenue Code, with active membership primarily consisting of students at an institution of higher education. Additionally, a consortium of higher education institutions in the same state is also considered eligible. Authorization of appropriations for this Act includes $25,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2011 to 2015.
